title: Development of YOLO-Based Fall Detection with Real-Time Monitoring System on Raspberry Pi 5
authors: Ngoc Anh Tran, Hoang Phuc Nguyen, Hoang-Loc Tran, Dinh-Duy Phan
publish: 2025 RIVF International Conference on Computing and Communication Technologies (RIVF)
abstract: Falls are a leading cause of serious injuries, particularly among the elderly, children, and workers in hazardous environments. To enhance safety and real-time monitoring, this study develops a YOLO-based fall detection system, deployed on the Raspberry Pi 5 platform. At its core, the system utilizes a YOLOv9 model retrained on an extensive dataset of over <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 7, 0 0 0}$</tex> images from various public sources. To address class imbalance and reduce false alarms, an additional 6,000 images of normal activities (Not_Fallen) were incorporated. After fine-tuning hyperparameters, the model achieved a high accuracy of 99.1 %, surpassing the reference study's mAP@0.5 score of 98.1 %. Experimental results demonstrate that the system operates efficiently, detecting falls with exceptional precision across diverse scenarios while maintaining realtime processing capability. This research establishes a strong foundation for future advancements, enabling the development of more sophisticated monitoring systems and expanding applications in safety and healthcare domains.

title: AgroFog+: Integrated IoT and AI System for Smart Greenhouse Management
authors: Shibagni Bhattacharjee, Raj Krish, Debajyoti Chatterjee, Suchanda Chatterjee
publish: 2025 13th International Conference on Intelligent Embedded, MicroElectronics, Communication and Optical Networks (IEMECON)
abstract: Protective growing in greenhouses requires precise environmental control, effective water usage, hazard management, and immediate monitoring of plant health. AgroFog+ is a low-cost, integrated IoT-based system that addresses these challenges through microclimate control, adaptive fogging, fire and gas hazard monitoring, and an AI-based assessment of plant stress. The system achieves optimal humidity and CO levels with soil-moisture responsive fogging, and it detects hazards in real time. The farmers can upload images of the plants, which are then analyzed with AI. The AI identifies diseases such as powdery mildew, recommends treatment, and automatically generates a detailed report sent via email. Experimental validation shows AgroFog+ stabilizes humidity, on-farm consumption of water, fast hazard detection, and detection of diseases for example, powdery mildew. AgroFog+ integrates environmental control, safety or hazard detection, and AI analysis of plant health into a single web-based system that is scalable, practical, and low- cost for smaller and mid-scale greenhouse growing opportunities, which promotes crop yield, efficient resource use, and potential preventative management of plants.

title: Health Monitoring System Development for Shielding Pumps in CSNS Target Station Cooling System
authors: Yu Liu, Ning He, Qiao Liang, Zhe Yang, Chuan Li, Huihong Liang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sensing, Measurement &amp; Data Analytics in the era of Artificial Intelligence (ICSMD)
abstract: To address the challenge of effective condition monitoring of shielded pumps in the water cooling system of the China Spallation Neutron Source (CSNS) target station under high radiation environments, this paper develops an intelligent fault diagnosis system based on multi-parameter fusion. The system integrates vibration sensors and current sensors to achieve multi-parameter monitoring, and establishes an integrated monitoring platform incorporating hardware system, software analysis, and database management. The system employs a threshold-based condition assessment method to realize real-time monitoring and fault warning, transforming the passive maintenance mode into a predictive maintenance strategy by replacing traditional offline inspection with online continuous monitoring. This system not only provides technical assurance for the safe and stable operation of the CSNS target station water cooling system, but also serves as a practical platform for health monitoring and fault diagnosis research of high-reliability equipment, demonstrating significant engineering application value.

title: ASDMD-GMM-UT Transfer-Driven RUL Probabilistic Prediction for Lithium-Ion Battery Packs
authors: Yihe Guo, Xipeng Wang, Jinzhen Kong, Dong Zhen, Guojin Feng, Hao Zhang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sensing, Measurement &amp; Data Analytics in the era of Artificial Intelligence (ICSMD)
abstract: Accurate remaining useful life (RUL) prediction of lithium-ion battery packs is essential for ensuring the reliability and safety of energy storage systems. However, the cross-domain transfer health prognosis from single cells to packs faces two major challenges: nonlinear and asynchronous degradation behaviors, and multimodal noises that violate the single-Gaussian assumption commonly used in traditional models. To address these issues, this study proposes an integrated framework for lithium-ion battery packs RUL prediction, synergistically combining an adaptive step-size differential model decomposition based on local curvature (ASDMD), and a Gaussian mixture model-based Unscented Transformation (GMM-UT). ASDMD adaptively regulates differential step sizes by local curvature estimation, ensuring the reduction of noise interference in smooth degradation phases and accurate capture of inflection points in steep degradation phases. GMM is employed to simultaneously model the statistical distributions of measurement noise and differential noise, while the UT realizes probabilistic propagation across domains. Three comparison methods are conducted to verify the accuracy and robustness of the proposed method. Experimental results show that the proposed method significantly improved prognostics performance for battery packs. In the migration prediction from battery cells to battery packs, the root mean square error for RUL prediction is less than 4 %, providing reliable guidance for maintenance scheduling and second-life utilization of battery systems.

title: Integrating Multi-Spectral Image Fusion and Path Planning Strategies for Effective Drone-Based Search and Rescue
authors: Semaa Amin, Mitchell Lawson, Kaitlyn Lowen, John Maunder, Ian Yip, Michal Aibin
publish: 2025 IEEE Canadian Conference on Electrical and Computer Engineering (CCECE)
abstract: In this paper, we investigate the integration of computer vision (CV) methodologies and advanced path planning strategies to enhance Search and Rescue (SAR) missions employing Remotely Piloted Aircraft Systems (RPAS), commonly known as drones. Effective SAR operations require rapid and accurate identification of missing or endangered individuals, which requires timely medical assistance to mitigate long-term health consequences. Traditional imaging techniques, such as RGB (visual) and thermal imaging, each present unique strengths and limitations within SAR contexts. To determine the most effective approach, we evaluated RGB, thermal and multispectral image fusion image datasets using the YOLO algorithm and four distinct path planning algorithms to optimize SAR missions: Scanline Fill, Quadrant Scanline Fill, Geocentric Fill, and Random Fill. We define multi-spectral image fusion as overlaying RGB and thermal imagery, enabling a combined view that leverages both modalities. Through extensive simulations, we verified that the Quadrant Scanline Fill algorithm consistently outperforms others in speed and efficiency, making it the most suitable choice for directing RPAS in search operations.

title: Conversational Smart Assistant on a Microcontroller with Cloud-Based LLM Function Offloading
authors: Dang Quoc-Minh Do, Nguyen Hoang Nguyen, Quang Nho-Dang Nguyen, Tuan Anh Hoang, Khoa Quoc Nguyen, Thuan Huu Huynh
publish: 2025 RIVF International Conference on Computing and Communication Technologies (RIVF)
abstract: This paper presents a conversational smart assistant architecture that integrates a resource-constrained microcontroller frontend with a cloud-based large language model (LLM) backend. The device captures user query audio, compresses it, and streams it in real time to the server over a lightweight custom TCP protocol. On the server, Google Speech-to-Text (STT) transcribes the input, which is then processed by OpenAI's Generative Pre-trained Transformer (GPT) model for natural language understanding. Depending on the query, the model either generates a direct response or issues structured function calls to access real-time information (e.g., breaking news) via public APIs or a headless browser, or to execute taskoriented functions such as reminder scheduling and voice note recording. The final response is synthesized into speech using Google Text-to-Speech (TTS), compressed and streamed back to the device for playback. Experimental results show low latency, efficient bandwidth usage, and cost-effective operation, demonstrating the practicality of the proposed architecture for embedded conversational interfaces and wearable IoT assistants.

title: Research on the Unbalanced Response Characteristics of Turbocharger Rotor System Under Transient Conditions
authors: Yinan Li, Hao Zhang, Guojin Feng, Dong Zhen
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sensing, Measurement &amp; Data Analytics in the era of Artificial Intelligence (ICSMD)
abstract: Turbochargers are widely used in highperformance internal combustion engine systems such as automobiles, aerospace, and marine applications. The floating ring bearing (FRB)-rotor system, as the core component, directly dictates turbocharger performance and durability. Its defining dual-oil-film structure enhances vibration damping on one hand, but simultaneously gives rise to significant nonlinear dynamic challenges, such as oil whirl, subsynchronous vibration, and bifurcation. A lubrication model for the FRB is developed based on the Reynolds equation with JFO cavitation boundary conditions. This model is then integrated with a finite element rotor model to establish a comprehensive nonlinear dynamic model of the turbocharger FRB-rotor system. Based on this, speed-up simulations were conducted for the system under balanced conditions and under different unbalanced conditions, systematically analyzing oil film instability behavior. The research results indicate that unbalanced excitation has a significant regulatory effect on oil whirl shedding, and the system may enter a chaotic state under specific operating conditions. Additionally, through methods such as waterfall plots, Poincare maps, and bifurcation analysis, the evolutionary of the system's nonlinear response was revealed. The findings deepen the insight into the physical mechanisms governing oil film instability in turbochargers, thereby contributing to the theoretical foundation needed for enhanced system design and more accurate vibration fault diagnosis.

title: Design of Multi-Beam Intelligent Reflecting Surface for 6G Wireless Communications
authors: Ngoc Tung Phung, Thanh Nam Le, Phuong Linh Nguyen, Quang Tuan Le, Khac Kiem Nguyen, Son Xuat Ta
publish: 2025 RIVF International Conference on Computing and Communication Technologies (RIVF)
abstract: Intelligent reflecting surface (IRS) is expected to become a key enabling technology in the future wireless communication networks (beyond 5 G or 6 G) due to its ability to dynamically control the radio wave propagation environment. Despite rapid advancements, most of the existing IRS researches still focus on a single-beam reflection. In this paper, a multibeam configuration for IRS is proposed, which is established based on 2-bit PIN diode unit cells with high reflectivity. Its reflection phase configurations are optimized by using genetic algorithm. To achieve the multi-beam operation, the IRS is configured by dividing into smaller sub-arrays, and each is independently configured to steer the reflected beam toward the desired direction. For computational demonstration, an IRS prototype composed of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$16 \times 16$</tex> unit cells is characterized, which can yield 2, 3, and 4-beam steering with low side-lobe level. This flexible approach enhances coverage performance and meets stringent communication requirements in complex scenarios such as the 6 G networks. Furthermore, the proposed architecture offers high scalability and can be easily adapted to the practical problems.

title: Interpretable and Reliable Soft Sensor Development in Industry 5.0
authors: Liang Cao, Jianping Su, Fan Yang, Yankai Cao, Bhushan Gopaluni
abstract: Dear Editor, This letter presents a new approach to developing interpretable and reliable soft sensors for Industry 5.0 applications. Although sophisticated machine learning methods have made remarkable strides in soft-sensor predictive accuracy, ensuring interpretability and reliable performance across varying industrial operating conditions remains a challenge [1]–[4]. This is precisely what Industry 5.0, proposed by the European Commission in 2021, advocates [5], [6]. It integrates various cutting-edge technologies, such as human-machine interaction, digital twins, cybersecurity and artificial intelligence, to facilitate the development of better soft sensors.

title: Exploratory Analysis and Temporal Dynamics of Air pollution in Bengaluru
authors: A Suresh, M N Saroja, S Kannan, A Sindhu, A Esakkiammal
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communication, Computing &amp; Industry 6.0 (C2I6)
abstract: The Indian cities have established air pollution as a critical environmental and health concern which affects the entire nation. The study evaluates Bengaluru’s Air Quality Index (AQI) data from 2017 to 2024 through detailed timebased and statistical methods. The research demonstrates that air pollution levels reach their peak during winter months from December to February but decrease substantially during the monsoon period from June to August. The 2020 COVID-19 lockdown resulted in substantial reductions of AQI values because of reduced human activity. The highest pollution levels occurred in 2019, but the AQI readings stayed mostly between 75 and 135 which falls under the ‘Moderate’ category. The pollution levels show a pattern of higher readings on weekdays because of vehicle and industrial emissions. The research demonstrates how urban growth interacts with weather conditions and human-made pollution sources to produce air quality changes. The research findings establish a data-based framework which enables urban planners to create effective sustainable air-quality management strategies for Bengaluru

title: A Novel Wideband X-band Amplifying Metasurface
authors: Zi-An Chen, Kun Liao, Shao-Bin Liu, Zhi-Chao Sun, Zheng-Yu Huang, Zi-Kang Liang, Xiang-Hua Xie, Jian-Ping Chang
publish: IEEE Antennas and Wireless Propagation Letters
abstract: In this letter, a novel X-band amplifying metasurface with power amplifiers is proposed to enhance the reflected electromagnetic (EM) signals. The amplifying metasurface is designed based on a receiving, amplifying, and polarization-converted reradiating scheme. To ensure wideband performance, a cross-aperture coupled patch unit cell is meticulously designed. According to simulation results, the amplifying metasurface exhibits a gain variation between 0 and 14 dB within the 7.1-9.9 GHz. The designed amplifying metasurface is then fabricated as a prototype and experimentally measured. The experimental measurements demonstrate good agreement with the simulated results. With the increasing demand for the high-capacity network, the proposed amplifying metasurface aligns with the key requirements of future wireless systems, particularly in scenarios requiring dynamic coverage control and signal enhancement.

title: Proactive Handover Management in 6G Low-Altitude Economy Networks for Aerial Vehicles Using Artificial General Intelligence
authors: Shikhar Verma, Sayantan Bose, Mostafa M. Fouda, Zubair Md Fadlullah, Diptendu Sinha Roy
publish: IEEE Transactions on Cognitive Communications and Networking
abstract: The rise of unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) and electric vertical take-off and landing (eVTOL) aircraft is accelerating the growth of the low-altitude economy (LAE), enabling mobility beyond conventional ground-based transport. However, aerial vehicles or flying vehicles (FVs) in LAE environments face significant communication challenges due to high mobility, frequent handovers between base stations (BSs), and the susceptibility of mmWave bands to blockage and path loss. Reactive handover mechanisms—triggered only after link degradation—often lead to disconnections and degraded service quality, particularly in dense urban areas. Moreover, uneven FV distribution can cause BS load imbalances, further compromising quality of service (QoS). To address these challenges, we propose a proactive BS association framework for intelligent handover management using artificial general intelligence (AGI). Our approach leverages deep learning to jointly predict future received signal strength indicator (RSSI) and BS load, enabling an autonomous decision algorithm to select optimal BSs for stable, high-throughput connectivity while minimizing unnecessary handovers. Simulation results demonstrate that the proposed joint prediction-based strategy significantly reduces handover frequency and improves average throughput compared to reactive, single-metric base-lines and two additional benchmark predictors introduced for extended evaluation. These findings underscore the potential of predictive, AGI-driven mobility management to enhance the stability and performance of communication networks in the emerging LAE ecosystem.

title: Neuron Membership Inference Attack in Federated Learning for bit Scenarios
authors: Ruihong Xiu, Junqing Le, Di Zhang, Xiaofeng Liao
publish: IEEE Transactions on Emerging Topics in Computational Intelligence
abstract: Federated learning (FL) is a secure approach to protecting client data privacy by remaining data local. However, semi-honest central servers expose clients to the risk of membership inference attacks (MIA). Differential privacy is often used to defend against MIA in FL, but the differential privacy-based federated learning (DP-FL) still faces the risk of privacy leakage for bit scenarios. This paper designs a novel neuron membership inference attack (NMIA) strategy under semi-honest central servers and bit scenarios, which can compromise DP-FL and obtain client privacy information. Specifically, NMIA generates an inference attack model with low computational overhead by training only in small-scale neurons. The attack model analyzes the gradient outputs of the FL clients and effectively infers information about specific client data. Sufficient conditions for the success of the NMIA have been theoretically proven. To comprehensively evaluate the performance of the NMIA strategy in bit scenarios, two differential privacy protection methods for randomized response encoding applicable to federated learning for bit scenarios (BDP-FL) are proposed. Experimental results show that NMIA can easily defeat traditional DP-FL, achieving an attack accuracy of over 99%, while NMIA’s attack accuracy in bit scenarios is about 20% higher than the existing attack strategies. In addition, NMIA can still defeat the optimized encoding BDP-FL with an attack accuracy of up to 90%, while the symmetric encoding BDP-FL can only mitigate NMIA at the cost of severe FL utility loss.

title: Experimental Characterization of Commercial Reduced Graphene Oxide Nanoplatelets for RF and Microwave Device Applications
authors: Luís Henrique Farias Schneider dos Santos, Candice Müller, Fernando César Comparsi de Castro, Ricardo Barreto da Silva
publish: 2025 SBMO/IEEE MTT-S International Microwave and Optoelectronics Conference (IMOC)
abstract: This paper presents the electrical characterization of different samples of commercially available reduced graphene oxide (RGO) nanoplatelets with distinct physical characteristics. The electrical response was evaluated in terms of resistance and transmittance variation as a function of the applied DC voltage and frequency. The reproducibility of the results and the behavior of the sample over multiple measurement cycles were evaluated. The results show that RGO nanoplatelets present significant resistance variation <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\Delta R$</tex> in the first measurement cycle. However, after the first cycle, RGO nanoplatelets undergo a resistance relaxation process, which significantly reduces the resistance and transmittance variation. The results also demonstrate that, over several measurement cycles, the resistive behavior tends to stabilize, but with a significantly reduced <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\Delta R$</tex>. Results indicate that further research and development on graphene is needed before its application in dynamically tunable RF and microwave devices, in order to reduce the resistance relaxation process and keep the behavior of the first cycle in the cycles that follow.

title: Multimodel Comparative Assessment and Optimal Geodetector-Driven Analysis of Aeolian Desertification in the Horqin Sandy Land
authors: Wanying Cao, Hanchen Duan, Beiying Huang, Xiaopeng Jia
publish: IEEE Journal of Selected Topics in Applied Earth Observations and Remote Sensing
abstract: The Horqin Sandy Land (HSL), a critical ecological barrier in northern China and core area of the Three-North Shelterbelt Project, requires precise monitoring of aeolian desertification (AD) dynamics to maintain ecological stability in densely populated northern and northeastern China. This study innovatively integrated multi-source remote sensing parameters via Google Earth Engine to systematically compare three feature space models (Albedo-NDVI, Albedo-MSAVI, Albedo-KNDVI) and five machine learning algorithms for AD monitoring, while applying the Optimal Parameter Geographic Detector (OPGD) to quantify natural-anthropogenic driving mechanisms. High-resolution AD classification (5-year intervals, 2000–2020) revealed spatiotemporal dynamics, with machine learning models consistently outperforming feature space models. Random Forest (RF) achieved the highest accuracy (97.7%) and Kappa coefficient (0.967), effectively distinguishing non-desertified areas from extreme desertification. Temporal analysis showed a significant AD reversal: total desertified area declined to 30,166.35 km² by 2020, driven by ecological policies and climate amelioration. OPGD analysis indicated soil texture as the strongest single driver (q > 0.48), but factor interactions (e.g., SD ∩︀ LU) exerted greater explanatory power, highlighting compound effects of natural and anthropogenic factors. This study provides a robust framework for high-precision AD monitoring in semi-arid agro-pastoral zones, supporting global efforts toward zero land degradation.

title: A Category-driven Depth-Scalable Inversion Framework for 3D GPR Data Inversion
authors: Xiujun Lin, Xiren Zhou, Xiangyu Wang, Huanhuan Chen
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: Inversion of three-dimensional Ground-Penetrating Radar (3D GPR) data risks nonlinear electromagnetic wave propagation and the structural diversity of subsurface targets. Existing deep learning methods typically adopt fixed-depth architectures for all inputs, disregarding variations in structural complexity among varying targets. This results in redundant computation in non-target background and limited accuracy for specific types of underground targets. In response, we propose the Category-driven Depth-Scalable Inversion (CDSI) framework that integrates target classification with category-driven inversion. CDSI simultaneously extracts dynamic features (i.e., the wave changing information) via specific reservoir computing and captures spatial features through a convolutional network. A cross-attention mechanism fuses these features to predict the target category. Guided by the predicted category, a depth-scalable inversion network further adjusts its depth to reconstruct permittivity maps. Experimental results on synthetic 3D GPR datasets demonstrate that CDSI consistently outperforms existing methods in both accuracy and computational efficiency.

title: A Unified Framework for Swarm Intelligence to Enhance Convergence and Reliability
authors: Saravanan G, Yuvaraj V, Ramasubramanian B, Lakshmi Devi R, Afsar Ali M, Akshaya TR
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Electrical, Control and Instrumentation Engineering (ICECIE)
abstract: This research focuses on creating and applying advanced meta heuristic algorithms for Optimization Problems. The primary goals are to improve the effectiveness and efficiency of nature-inspired algorithms and to solve complex optimization problems in multiple areas. The research describes a number of algorithms that utilize principles of swarm intelligence, such as Particle Swarm Optimization, to address problems in machine learning, robotics, and data analysis. The goal is to enable researchers and practitioners to use these algorithms on various real-life challenges to enhance the processes and outcomes of optimization. This study not only serves scholarly interests but also has real-world application value, catalyzing the use of advanced methods for solving optimization problems. It is shown that all algorithms are implemented in Python, which ensures that a large audience is able to use and access them easily. Each algorithm is accompanied by comprehensive documentation, which offers detailed explanations and illustrative examples, thus enabling users to easily understand and incorporate the algorithms into their projects. Application of these meta-heuristic algorithms is anticipated to improve not just the optimization processes but also the resultant performance across a wide spectrum of tasks. Such findings motivate practitioners and specialists to actively participate in fostering collaboration and further development within the research community, thereby further advancing methodologies in swarm intelligence. This study's findings are of considerable significance with respect to artificial intelligence and optimization, offering a basis for subsequent advancements. The ongoing refinement of these algorithms may provide, at some point, solutions for addressing more sophisticated issues, which will, in turn, promote breakthroughs in technology and engineering.

title: A Study on Dispersion Characteristics of a Gyrator-Loaded CRLH-TL with an Even Number of Unit Cells
authors: Kensuke Okubo, Mitsuyoshi Kishihara, Koichiro Sakaguchi
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Radio-Frequency Integration Technology (RFIT)
abstract: This paper investigates the dispersion characteristics of a gyrator-loaded composite right/left-handed transmission line (CRLH-TL) with an even number of unit cells, which we refer to as the E-CRLH-TL. This structure exhibits both high tunability of the operating frequency and reciprocal transmission behavior. In this paper, to facilitate circuit prototyping, a simplified configuration is considered, in which series capacitors are placed on both sides of the gyrators. The dispersion equation for this structure is derived, and numerical analysis shows that its characteristics closely match those of the original configuration over a wide frequency range, except near the higher cutoff frequency. Furthermore, since it has been confirmed that the dispersion diagrams of the E-CRLH-TL and the conventional CRLH-TL coincide under a specific structural condition, the simplified version is shown to maintain similar transmission performance while offering improved ease of implementation.

title: Artificial Intelligence in HRM: Linking Ethical Design, Digital Well-being, and Green HRM for Sustainable Performance
authors: Waseem Umer, Rakhshanda Furnaz, Burhan Sadiq, Ammara Naseem, Tayyeba Bashir
publish: 2025 Horizons of Information Technology and Engineering (HITE)
abstract: This study investigates how AI-ethical design factors influence organizational sustainable performance through the mediating roles of employee digital well-being and Green Human Resource Management (GHRM) outcomes. Drawing on AMO theory and socio-technical systems theory, a cross-sectional survey was conducted, with 550 responses collected and 509 valid samples analyzed using Partial Least Squares Structural Equation Modeling (PLSSEM). The results demonstrate that ethical AI design enhances employee digital well-being, which positively drives GHRM outcomes and, in turn, strengthens sustainable organizational performance. Mediation analyses further confirm sequential pathways linking AI ethics, well-being, and GHRM practices to sustainability. The findings extend existing HRM and AI ethics literature by integrating digital well-being into the GHRM–sustainability nexus, while providing practical guidance for managers to embed ethical AI principles, foster employee well-being, and institutionalize sustainability-focused HRM practices. Keywords: Artificial Intelligence, Ethical AI, Green HRM, Digital Well-being, Sustainability

title: Synthetic Inertia in Small Inverters: A New Strategy Based on DC Link Current Control*
authors: Luiz Fernando Marquez Arruda, Guilherme Beck Lemos, Roberto Francisco Coelho, Denizar Cruz Martins
abstract: This paper presents a control strategy for small-scale photovoltaic (PV) inverters to introduce synthetic inertia into the power grid. As the participation of renewable sources increases and conventional synchronous generators decrease, grid stability may be affected since PV inverters lack inherent inertia. A current control model for the DC-Link is proposed to improve the inertia, integrating a two-stage single-phase inverter with a bidirectional boost converter and a battery bank. This system acts as a synthetic inertia source, using battery charge and discharge to smooth power transitions and enhance grid stability. Based on the Swing Equation of synchronous generators, the strategy implements a virtual inertia response, reducing oscillations and improving system dynamics. Simulations on a 3 kW inverter show improved response time and smoother transitions, indicating this approach is a promising solution to increase renewable energy integration while maintaining grid stability.

title: Vaku: Web Application for the Management of Child Vaccination at the Emiro Quintero CañIzares Hospital in Ocaña
authors: Nelson Mauricio Navarro Zaraza, Noemi Collantes Reyes, Duvan Andrey Marquez Pinzón, Mauricio Alfredo Zafra Aycardi, Dewar Rico-Bautista
publish: 2025 Congreso Internacional de Innovación y Tendencias en Ingeniería (CONIITI)
abstract: Childhood vaccination coverage has declined alarmingly in several regions of Latin America, especially in areas such as Ocaña, Norte de Santander (Colombia), which has generated public health concern. Socioeconomic, cultural, and structural factors, and particularly the deterioration or loss of the physical card, have interrupted the adequate follow-up of the vaccination schedule. This article presents a technological solution centered on a web application that allows health personnel to efficiently manage child immunization records and parents to consult their children's immunization status. The proposed solution strengthens digital capabilities in local health centers, through a user-friendly interface that improves traceability in the vaccination schedule, which seeks to ensure constant access to immunization data, contributing to an increase in the vaccination rate in the population.

title: Knowledge-Based Behavioral Biometrics for Secure Authentication in Virtual Reality
authors: Numan Zafar, Priyo Ranjan Kundu Prosun, Shafique Ahmad Chaudhry
abstract: Virtual Reality (VR) transforms daily activities into immersive experiences, bridging the gap between physical and virtual environments. The growing use of VR applications to handle sensitive personal data necessitates the development of authentication methods that are both secure and practical. Traditional PIN-based systems remain susceptible to theft, spoofing, and credential sharing, while previous behavior-based biometrics often restrict trajectories to fixed lengths and overlook device heterogeneity. This study presents the first VR authentication framework that integrates knowledge-based PIN entry with behavioral biometrics derived from cross-device input modalities, incorporating both controller and hand-tracking trajectories to enhance the security. We evaluate a Siamese network designed to process variable-length motion data using a pilot dataset of 26 participants performing four distinct PIN-entry tasks. The proposed approach achieves authentication accuracies up to 96%, with Equal Error Rates (EERs) as low as <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{2. 9 5 \%}$</tex>. By preserving natural temporal variability and generating match scores, this method enables authentication to generalize across devices and users, thereby establishing a foundation for secure and deployable VR access control systems.

title: KUL-BPS: A Bearing Testing Platform in Addressing Data Scarcity in Condition Monitoring
authors: Junyu Qi, Zhen Li, Alexandre Mauricio, Konstantinos Gryllias
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sensing, Measurement &amp; Data Analytics in the era of Artificial Intelligence (ICSMD)
abstract: Condition monitoring (CM) is vital for ensuring the reliability and safety of rotating machinery in industrial applications. Despite significant advances in signal processing and machine learning techniques, progress in CM research remains constrained by the scarcity of high-quality degradation datasets. Acquiring such data, particularly for fault prognostics, faces multiple challenges. First, constructing an experimental test rig requires substantial investment and multidisciplinary expertise in mechanical design, control systems, and measurement technologies. Second, generating meaningful prognostic datasets demands large numbers of bearing failures under diverse operating conditions to adequately represent different degradation patterns. Third, the degradation process often takes several days to months, making it both time- and resource-intensive. As a result, few comprehensive datasets are publicly available due to commercial confidentiality and limited test capacities. To address these challenges and contribute to the CM community, we present the KU Leuven Bearing Prognostics Setup (KUL-BPS), a novel, modular, and cost-effective Accelerated Lifetime Testing (ALT) platform designed for systematic bearing degradation testing. Unlike existing ALT setups, which are often limited to low loads <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(<10 \text{kN})$</tex>, low speeds (<3000 RPM), or artificially induced faults, KUL-BPS offers several key advantages: (a) It supports high loads up to 35 kN and speeds up to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$18,000 \text{RPM}$</tex>, enabling realistic wear and fatigue processes; (b) It utilizes a robust self-aligning bearing, which is easy to install, inspect, and replace; (c) It allows experiments under both constant and time-varying load-speed profiles to reflect real-world operating conditions. Furthermore, KUL-BPS enables synchronized acquisition of multiple sensing modalities, including vibration, torque, speed, force, acoustics, displacement, and temperature, facilitating comprehensive CM studies. The platform also supports virtual sensing research, such as estimating internal forces or torques from indirect measurements.

title: Reflective Photoplethysmography Sensing Interface Designs on Chest for Improved Signal Quality*
authors: Zifei He, Yutong Zhang, Yiqing Yao, Zhipeng Cai, Lulu Zhao, Yongxin Chou, Qun Wei, Jianqing Li, Chengyu Liu, Chenxi Yang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sensing, Measurement &amp; Data Analytics in the era of Artificial Intelligence (ICSMD)
abstract: To accommodate multi-modal measurements, photoplethysmography (PPG) sensors have to be placed at nonstandard body sites, such as the chest, where unstable sensorskin contact commonly degrades signal quality. In this case, this paper presented a low-cost consideration of sensing interface that improves the signal quality of reflective PPG. Major designs were raised sensing surface and all-in-one electrode. The raised sensing surface helps the light-emitting diode (LED) and photodiode (PD) maintain flexible, close attachment to the skin. The all-in-one electrode with an open window and double-sided tape provides stable mechanical support. In this paper, two prototypes - one baseline (flat surface, separate electrodes) and one improved (raised surface, all-in-one electrode) - were tested simultaneously in 15 healthy subjects. Signal quality was compared using the PQR signal-quality indexes (rSQI) and SNR. The improved device outperformed the conventional one, with an average rSQI increase of +4.01 (infrared) and +2.08 (red), and an SNR improvement of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{+ 7. 8 6 d B}$</tex> (infrared) and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\boldsymbol{+} \mathbf{1 6. 7 5 d B}$</tex> (red). Using off-the-shelf parts and simple processes, the proposed designs effectively suppress low-frequency noise and enhance reflectance PPG quality at low cost.

title: Advancing Transmission Use of System (TUoS) Pricing in Saudi Arabia: A Technical Exploration
authors: M. S. Almajed, E. Q. Novenario, B. K. Al-Gthami
abstract: The structuring of Transmission Use of System (TUoS) pricing represents a pivotal technical and economic challenge within modern electricity market design, directly influencing investment signals, operational efficiency, and the integration of renewable energy sources. This paper presents a rigorous technical analysis of the evolutionary pathway for TUoS charges, drawing upon well-established international benchmarks. Utilizing a comprehensive phased modeling approach—progressing from a simple postage stamp model to the current peak-coincident framework and finally to an advanced zonal pricing methodology—this study applies a simplified DC load flow analysis, executed in a Python environment, to a representative model of the Saudi national grid. The modeling results provide quantifiable evidence of significant locational disparities in network costs, demonstrating that a strategic transition to a zonal model would substantially enhance economic efficiency by providing transparent, cost-reflective signals to guide optimal generation siting and demand-side management. Furthermore, this analysis establishes a technically robust and defensible foundation for calculating precise wheeling charges between zones—an important institutional enabler for third-party market access and competition, in line with broader liberalization goals. This study also offers practical insights into how Saudi Arabia's tariff structures could align with global technical practices, helping to support the Kingdom's Vision 2030 objectives for economic and energy diversification. The analysis is conducted with full respect for the significant progress already achieved by the national utility and regulator, and is intended solely as a technical contribution to the ongoing dialogue on strengthening the Kingdom's energy sector governance for a sustainable and efficient future [1].

title: Next-Gen Offshore Wind Year Ahead Forecasting Aided Modelling for Techno-Economic Feasibility
authors: Nidhi Gummaraju, C Shri Varshini, Mamilla Sree Vyshnavi, Greeshma Potnuru, K. Shanti Swarup
abstract: Offshore wind power development entails high uncertainty in the form of fluctuating resources, intricate grid integration, and finance risk. This paper proposes an integrated solution that unites wind resource evaluation, machine learning–based predictions, physics-constrained simulation, and techno-economic optimization to enhance the reliability and profitability of offshore wind farms. The model integrates high-resolution spatiotemporal information with a prediction module using the Extra Trees regressor, having a determination coefficient of R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> = 0.999. The simulation of physics-based turbine dynamics and high-voltage direct current (HVDC) transmission is used to calculate the operational stability and transmission loss. In addition, Monte Carlo-based measures of risk including De-Risked Wind Power Availability (DWPA) and Weighted Annual Revenue Reliability (WARR) are employed to quantify the impact of uncertainty in the market returns. A case study of a 1 GW offshore installation off the coast of Tamil Nadu illustrates a mean capacity factor of about 48% and a levelized cost of energy of 65–75 USD/MWh. These results indicate that the combined framework can substantially reduce techno-economic risk while supporting data-driven decision-making for large-scale offshore wind deployment.

title: Long-Range Active Acoustic Sensing Based on Microwave Vibration Measurement
authors: Zhiqiang Kang, Haibin Meng, Yuyong Xiong, Xiangyi Tang, Wendi Tian
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sensing, Measurement &amp; Data Analytics in the era of Artificial Intelligence (ICSMD)
abstract: This paper presents a long-range active acoustic sensing method based on microwave vibration measurement. Conventional microphones suffer from severe performance degradation in long-distance sound acquisition due to acoustic energy attenuation and environmental interference, while laser-based solutions are limited by high cost and sensitivity to ambient conditions. To address these challenges, we propose an approach that employs a frequency-modulated continuous-wave (FMCW) radar system to measure the phase variations of reflected microwave signals, thereby estimating the minute vibrations of sound-producing objects and reconstructing the corresponding acoustic signals. The vibration measurement principle is derived in detail, and multiple experiments are conducted with sound sources placed up to 10 meters away. The results verify that the proposed method effectively acquires various types of sound signals at long range while maintaining robustness against environmental noise. This work demonstrates the feasibility of microwave-based acoustic sensing as a promising alternative to conventional methods for remote sound acquisition.

title: Active Disturbance Rejection Controller Applied to Speed Control of Electromagnetic Frequency Regulator
authors: Gabriel P. de Oliveira, Aziz O-S. Bissiriou, José R. D. Neto, Tadeu F. dos Santos, Ricardo F. Pinheiro, Andrés O. Salazar
abstract: This study presents a novel control strategy for regulating the rotor speed of the Electromagnetic Frequency Regulator (EFR) in Hybrid Renewable Energy Systems (HRESs), based on Active Disturbance Rejection Control (ADRC). The EFR, which couples wind and photovoltaic sources through a single-stage power conversion system, requires accurate speed control to ensure stable output frequency in the synchronous generator. Unlike conventional Proportional - Integral (PI) controllers, which are sensitive to parameter uncertainties and external disturbances, ADRC actively estimates and compensates both internal and external perturbations, thus improving overall system robustness. Simulation results show that ADRC reduces speed oscillations by up to 80% during load variations and maintains frequency deviations within 2% of the nominal value, without overshoot. These results underscore ADRC's effectiveness in enhancing stability and power quality in hybrid renewable energy applications.

title: Secure Acceleration of Aggregation Queries over Homomorphically Encrypted Databases
authors: Jinjiang Yang, Chunyi Zhang, Feng Liu, Yingjie Xue, Feng Wang, Kaiping Xue
publish: IEEE Transactions on Information Forensics and Security
abstract: Recent advancements in Fully Homomorphic Encryption (FHE) have significantly impacted encrypted database management, particularly in secure data querying. However, FHE poses notable performance challenges, especially in processing aggregation queries. These challenges stem from the need to homomorphically evaluate selection predicates via a linear scan over encrypted rows and from the resultant accumulation of redundant data. Overcoming these limitations necessitates innovative solutions that transcend traditional FHE optimizations. We propose a scheme, named Accelerated Homomorphically Encrypted DataBase (AHEDB), to enhance the efficiency of aggregation queries in homomorphically encrypted databases. In the scheme, we employ Encrypted Multiple Maps (EMM) to reduce the computational load inherent in homomorphic operations, thereby achieving significant improvements over existing encryption schemes. We further introduce Single Range Cover (SRC) algorithm for range and equality indexing to address potential security vulnerabilities. We implement our scheme and conduct comparative analyses with FHE-based database system. Our experiments demonstrate that our scheme offers significant advantages in querying overheads, striking a balance between security and efficiency.

title: Self-Recovery and Fault-Tolerant Control of Distributed Piezoelectric Stack Actuators Under Temperature Perturbation and Layer Breakdown
authors: Jie Ling, Yunzhi Zhang, Congan Xie, Micky Rakotondrabe, Yuchuan Zhu
abstract: Aerospace actuators must deliver high-speed, high-precision performance while withstanding extreme temperatures and environmental variations, which pose significant challenges to their positioning accuracy and reliability. To address these issues, this article proposes a fault decoupling and fault-tolerant control (FTC) scheme for distributed piezoelectric stack actuators (PSAs), enabling self-diagnosis and self-recovery. A temperature perturbation observer (TPO) is designed to estimate temperature-induced disturbances, and a fault decoupling sliding mode observer (FDeSMO) is developed to decouple layer breakdown faults from lumped disturbances. The coordination between the two observers allows accurate detection of broken layers under temperature variations. Subsequently, a fault-tolerant controller is integrated to reallocate control signals and ensure system stability. Experimental results validate the proposed scheme, demonstrating its ability to detect fault and maintain reliability under the fault occurrence and temperature variation (<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\textbf{19}\!\boldsymbol{\sim}\!\textbf{60}\,{}^{\boldsymbol{\circ}}\textbf{C}$</tex-math> </inline-formula>). title: Soft Actor-Critic-Based Early Warning Method for Quench Risk in High-Temperature Superconducting Cables
authors: Jiawei Hao, Sixiang Xue, Chang Li, Jixiang Liu, Rui Wang, Menghua Deng, Pengyu You
abstract: To address the challenge of predicting quench risks in high-temperature superconducting (HTS) cables under multiple-source disturbances, this paper proposes an intelligent early-warning method based on the Soft Actor-Critic (SAC) algorithm. At first, a multi-index evaluation system covering electrical and cooling characteristics is constructed, and the entropy weight method is adopted to determine the weights for comprehensive risk quantification. Secondly, a deep reinforcement learning model based on SAC is established to achieve dynamic risk prediction under continuous operating conditions. Finally, multi-scenario experiments and comparative analysis with other mainstream early-warning methods demonstrate that the proposed approach achieves effective early quench warning, with prediction errors consistently maintained within acceptable ranges.

title: Automatic Generation of Open Data-Based Traffic Simulation Model
authors: Hyunyoung Ryu, Jitaek Lim, Minseok Song
abstract: Open transportation data is becoming more accessible, creating new opportunities for data-driven traffic simulation. However, transforming this data into a simulation-ready model is complex and time-consuming. This study introduces an automated framework to generate city-scale traffic simulation models using open data, including road networks, traffic signals, and vehicle volumes. Built on the Simulation of Urban Mobility (SUMO), the pipeline streamlines data processing and integrates real-world inputs into simulation components. The framework combines multiple open datasets through hybrid data synthesis, ensuring consistent road–signal coordination and enhancing traffic-flow realism and spatial resolution. Applied to a real urban center, the resulting models showed strong alignment with observed traffic patterns, supporting validity. As data collection, real-time monitoring, and spatial resolution advance, the framework’s applicability and precision will improve. By enabling efficient and reproducible model generation, this approach contributes to scalable traffic simulation and lays the groundwork for urban digital twin applications.

title: Second-Order Filtering for Internal Model Control Tuned PID Controllers
authors: Atilla Uygur
publish: 2025 IEEE 22nd International Conference on Sciences and Techniques of Automatic Control and Computer Engineering (STA)
abstract: Proportional-Integral-Derivative (PID) control has long been the backbone of many industrial control systems due to its cost-effectiveness, simplicity of design, and robustness. Internal Model Control (IMC) is one of the most effective approaches for tuning PID controller parameters. Typically, first-order low-pass filters are employed in the IMC-based process control, where the filter has only one tuning parameter, namely closed-loop time constant, $\lambda$. Even when a second-order filter is used, it still has only one tuning parameter. This study investigates the effect of second-order filtering with two userdefined parameters and employs analog filter denominator polynomials to determine the initial controller parameters. A novel second-order filtering model is proposed for first-order plus time delay (FOPTD) processes, and second-order low-pass Butterworth and Bessel polynomials are utilized to derive initial PID tuning parameters. The performance of the resulting controllers is evaluated through simulations in terms of setpoint tracking, load disturbance rejection, and robustness to model uncertainties for two FOPTD processes.

title: Study of Energy Flow in a Standalone Hybrid PV/Fuel Cell System
authors: Tawfik Soltani, Monia Ben Khader Bouzid
publish: 2025 IEEE 22nd International Conference on Sciences and Techniques of Automatic Control and Computer Engineering (STA)
abstract: As part of the global energy transition, ensuring the autonomy of isolated sites is a major challenge, particularly in sunny regions such as Tunisia. Photovoltaic (PV) and hydrogen-based technologies are recognized as renewable sources for efficient and sustainable electricity generation. This paper presents a detailed analysis of a hybrid system that integrates a PV array with a proton exchange membrane fuel cell (PEMFC) to supply a constant 6 kW load. Furthermore, simulations were performed in MATLAB/Simulink to investigate the dynamic behavior of the system under various solar irradiation conditions. The outcomes of this study provide valuable insights into the overall performance of the hybrid PV/PEMFC system and contribute to advancing sustainable solutions for isolated energy applications.

title: Semantic Memory Synthesis: Hierarchical Knowledge Integration and Temporal Reasoning for Autonomous Agents
authors: Raghavendra Kamat
publish: 2025 Seventh International Conference on Research in Computational Intelligence and Communication Networks (ICRCICN)
abstract: Large Language Model (LLM) agents require memory architectures that transcend static data repositories, enabling continuous learning and dynamic adaptation. Current memory systems suffer from structural inflexibility, insufficient temporal reasoning capabilities, and inability to synthesize higher-order insights from experiential data. We present Semantic Memory Synthesis, a novel memory framework built around a multilayered Spatio-Temporal Resonance Graph (STRG) that manages semantically enriched Insight Particles (IPs) and autonomously synthesizes Insight Aggregates (IAs) through a Semantic Oracle Interface (SOI). The system interconnects information via typed Relational Strands and employs Cognitive Refinement processes orchestrated by the Nexus Weaver (NW). Experimental evaluation demonstrates Semantic Memory Synthesis’s superiority over existing approaches, achieving a $34 \%$ improvement in task completion rates for long-horizon planning and a $\mathbf{4 2} \boldsymbol{\%}$ reduction in query latency compared to state-of-the-art baselines, while maintaining enhanced coherence in multi-session dialogues.

title: Spatial Knowledge Graph Creation and Action Prediction with Neuro Symbolic AI
authors: Debamrita Paul, Akash Bhakat, Saikat Panda, Kousik Dasgupta
publish: 2025 Seventh International Conference on Research in Computational Intelligence and Communication Networks (ICRCICN)
abstract: Accurate perception and reasoning in driving environments remain critical challenges for autonomous vehicles. Traditional deep learning based perception systems, while powerful at detecting objects, often lack interpretability and fail to generalize in ambiguous or unseen conditions. To address these limitations, we propose a Neuro-Symbolic Spatial Graph architecture that integrates neural perception with symbolic reasoning for context aware scene understanding. The system employs a convolutional vision model to perform object detection, distance estimation from raw driving footage. The extracted spatial information is then structured into a symbolic scene graph, where nodes represent entities such as vehicles, lanes and the camera mounted car. Edges in the graph encode spatial and semantic relations, including distance, lane occupancy and proximity warnings. This hybrid representation enables the system to infer high level contextual insights such as collision risk and optimal maneuver zones. Experimental results demonstrate that our approach supports interpretability, logical reasoning about spatial interactions.

title: Feasibility of Quantum Cryptography with AES for Secure Communication
authors: Nurul Muzfirah Binti Mustaffa, Nurulain Balqis Binti Mat Daud, Takumi Sase
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology for the Muslim World (ICT4M)
abstract: Traditional encryption techniques face serious threats from the rapid development of quantum computing, which could soon compromise many classical algorithms. To address this, new quantum-resistant security methods are needed to protect private data and communications. This paper proposes a hybrid encryption approach that integrates quantum key distribution (QKD) with a simplified 3×3 advanced encryption standard (AES) key matrix, creating a lightweight system. The objective is to provide an efficient encryption method suitable for devices with limited processing power, such as IoT devices. The model was simulated using Qiskit, achieving an average quantum bit error rate of 0.00%, protocol efficiency of 49.72 %, and quantum fidelity of 1.000 under certain conditions. During eavesdropping scenarios, the error rate increased to 16.90 %. The simplified AES achieved a 50.14 % avalanche effect and an encryption time of 0.3073 ms, reducing latency by 17 % compared to standard AES. These results suggest that combining QKD with lightweight AES can provide quantum resilience and computational efficiency, offering a practical solution for secure communication in the post-quantum era.

title: Grounded CPW with a longitudinal slot at the bottom ground for loss reduction at the sub-THz band on glass IPD
authors: Ruei-Ze Lin, Zhi-Ting Yang, Hsin-Chia Lu
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Radio-Frequency Integration Technology (RFIT)
abstract: Grounded CPW with a longitudinal slot at the bottom ground under the signal trace is proposed to reduce the loss of the transmission line at the sub-THz band. Adding a slot under the signal trace redistributes the E-field to the gaps between the signal trace and the two side-grounds. With a larger area for E-field distribution, the loss can be reduced. The wider the slot, the lower the loss in simulation and measurement. At slot widths of 40 μm and 50 μm, the losses are reduced by 37% and 40% at 140 GHz as compared with the traditional GCPW. At 300 GHz, the losses are reduced by 27% and 34%.

title: Optimizing RIS-Assisted D2D Networks with Energy Constrained Nodes Using Differentiable Projection-Based Approaches
authors: Nikita Egorov, Joel Algera, Omer Waqar
publish: 2025 IEEE Canadian Conference on Electrical and Computer Engineering (CCECE)
abstract: This paper investigates sum-rate maximization for reconfigurable intelligent surface (RIS)-assisted device-to-device (D2D) networks with energy constrained nodes. Given the highdimensional and non-convex nature of the underlying optimization problem, obtaining a global optimal solution presents a significant challenge. To this end, we propose two novel differentiable projection-based approaches that provide high-quality sub-optimal solutions while guaranteeing to satisfy the energy harvesting constraints, i.e., achieve zero constraint violation. Numerical results are provided that show superiority of our proposed approaches over the benchmark schemes in achieving higher sum-rates. In particular, it is demonstrated that one of our proposed approaches achieves up to 3.68 times higher sum-rate when compared to the benchmark schemes.
